sn15.1:1.1: This chapter links to the Nidānasaṁyutta through the concept of beginningless transmigration, in which beings are lost because of not understanding dependent origination (SN 12.60:2.3).
sn15.1:1.7: Resolve anamatagga as ana’mat’agga, where ana is a doubled negative: “no known beginning”. | The idea stems from the the Nāsadīya Sūkta, which twice mentions “in the beginning” (agre, Rig Veda 10.129.3, 4; see too 10.90.7, 10.121.1). There, from thought (manaso) evolved desire. It concludes, ”This creation—from where it came to be, if it was produced or if not—he who is the overseer of this (world) in the furthest heaven, he surely knows. Or if he does not know …?” (Rig Veda 10.129.7, Jamison/Brereton).
sn15.1:1.8: We encountered a slight variation of this phrase at SN 12.19:1.2.
sn15.1:1.9: The “Black Plum Tree Land” is jambudīpa, the South Asian subcontinent, including India, Pakistan, Nepal, Bangladesh, and Afghanistan.
